thread.title: Hunt is on for the last golden fiver
thread.title_full: Hunt is on for the last golden fiver

title: Hunt is on for the last golden fiver
text: Share this article Share Mr Short painstakingly carved tiny 5mm portraits of the novelist onto the polymer cash, next to the images of Sir Winston Churchill and Big Ben. The outline of the golden engraving is visible to the naked eye - but a microscope is needed to see it properly. Each image of the Pride and Prejudice author is surrounded by a unique quote from some of her most celebrated novels. The Birmingham-based artist released the notes into circulation last year, one in England, Scotland Wales and Northern Ireland. Pictured: A new £5 note Mr Short is most famous for engraving the words of the Lord's Prayer on to the head of a pin. When he released the notes, the 70-year-old artist said: 'I'm always looking to do something different and as soon as I saw the new £5 note I thought 'wouldn't it be good if I could engrave something on it?' 'I didn't know what but then I found out it was going to be the 200th anniversary of Jane Austen's death and her image is also going on the new £10 note, so it ties in nicely with that.' The first five was found in December last year by a customer taking change from a sausage and egg sandwich at a café in Blackwood, south Wales.
